title: Rutland Water Walk and Cycle Route

images.title: Kate Jewell / Cycleway, Rutland Water
images.caption: Cycleway, Rutland Water. The route used to go straight ahead here but has been diverted to avoid the sensitive water line in the Nature Reserve.

images.title: Kate Jewell / Rutland Water
images.caption: Rutland Water. This is the final part of the road from Hambleton to Normanton before it disappears under the water. Normanton Park Hotel and the Museum can be seen on the opposite shore

images.title: Derek Bradley / Rutland Water
images.caption: Rutland Water Visitor Centre. The visitor centre is located at the bottom of the main car park. It consists of a café, souvenir shop and information kiosk. At the rear of the building can be seen the Fishing Lodge.

images.title: Chris J Dixon / Boats on Barnsdale Creek, Rutland Water
images.caption: Boats on Barnsdale Creek, Rutland Water. Looking E from the southern shore.

images.title: Kate Jewell / From Crake Hide, Rutland Water
images.caption: View from the Crake Bird Hide. This part of the south arm of Rutland Water is divided up by stone "breakwaters" into linked lagoons. Water flowing from Lagoon III can be seen between the willows on the left of the picture.

images.title: Kate Jewell / Pump House at Rutland Water
images.caption: A 20th century pumphouse by the dam.

images.title: Mat Fascione / Atop the dam at Rutland Water
images.caption: Atop the dam. The Rutland Water Circular Route runs along the top of the dam with track shown in this photo. The trees are Cow Croft Spinney near Empingham in Rutland.

images.title: Kate Jewell / View from Lapwing Hide, Rutland Water
images.caption: View from Lapwing Hide. The west end of Rutland Water is devoted to a large nature reserve. This view is looking southeast along the South Arm of the reservoir from one of the many birdwatching hides along the shore.

description: This splendid Nature Reserve has a fabulous cycling and walking path around the perimeter of the huge artificial lake.  The route starts at Oakham and soon joins the waterside path towards Whitwell and the nearby Butterfly centre.  You continue to Edith Weston, Manton and Egleton where you will find the birdwatching centre at Egleton Bay. Rutland water is excellent for birdwatching with a wide variety of winged visitors including Osprey, Cormorant and Lapwing. Cycle hire is available at Whitwell. Three long distance walking trails run along the lake. You can pick up the Macmillan Way, Hereward Way or Viking Way to extend your walking in the area. For cyclists National Cycle Route 63 runs along the lake. It will take you through the heart of the National Forest from Burton on Trent to Wisbech
